https://github.com/facebook/zstd/releases/tag/v1.4.5

That release should be faster.

items.title: Improve performance by supporting multi-threaded compression
items.body:
Thank you for your hard work.

I just wonder if python-zstd can be much faster by using multi-threaded compression?

I tried comprssing a 800MB+ data, it takes python-zstd 0.48s, faster than zstandard, which is 0.67s.

However, zstandard supports multi-threaded compression, and when I use 6 threads, it only takes 0.17s.

I don't really mean to compare or judge, but I personally believe your implement is more performant, and python-zstd can be more perfect if it supports multi-threaded compression. Thanks.

items.title: Improve docs for zstd.compress
items.body:
The docstring for `zstd.compress` is currently:

```
Compress string, returning the compressed data.
Raises an exception if any error occurs.
```

This has a few issues:

1. It does not specify that there are two arguments (`string` and `level`)
1. It does not specify the possible options for `level`
1. It doesn't say how illegal `level` values will be handled

For comparison, here is the `zlib.compress` docstring:

```
compress(string[, level]) -- Returned compressed string.

Optional arg level is the compression level, in 0-9. 
```

Following this lead, I suggest a `zstd.compress` docstring like this:

```
compress(string[, level]) -- Returned compressed string.

Optional arg level is the compression level, from 1 (fastest) to 22
(slowest). The default value is 3. Compression values outside the valid
range will be clipped to valid values.
```

I also want to add a few comments to that suggested docstring...

1. Looking into your code I see that you seem to allow compression levels down to `-5`. Why is this?
    * I don't understand the reasoning here, which is primarily why this is an Issue vs a PR
1. My personal opinion is that incorrect levels should raise a `ValueError`, rather than silently clipping.
    * Clipping can be confusing (especially with the absence of valid level ranges in the docstring)
    * The Zstandard implementation uses -1 through -22, and I wasn't sure whether your implementation took the negatives literally or not, so I needed to dig into your C code. A `ValueError` would have immediately clarified when I invoked incorrectly.
    * The docstring could be built to include `ZSTD_MAX_CLEVEL` and `ZSTD_MIN_CLEVEL` as "write-less-code-later insurance" against this range every getting expanded
    * If `ValueError` were raised, the clipping statement in the suggested docstring could just be removed.

items.title: Update to 1.3.3 upstream version
items.body: It should be stable I hope.

items.title: upload zstd to conda
items.body:
or conda-forge

this will be great!

items.title: add a open and close (the "with" interface)
items.body:
gzip has a nice interface for compressing:
like this:

```
    import gzip
    with gzip.open(filename, 'rb') as f:
        return f.read()
```

this is a very nice interface.
can you support it also?

items.title: Support frame format
items.body:
ZSTD has 2 formats:
- A block format, using `ZSTD_compress` and `ZSTD_decompress`
- A frame format for arbitrary file length

I may have missed it, but I didn't find a way to decompress frame format using this library, or to compress a file into a frame format.

items.title: Support build with external libzstd
items.body: As of Ubuntu Xenial has package libzstd-dev (0.5.1) and Debian Testing (9.0) too.

items.title: Support dictionary training and using it
items.body: The main issue is to pass file-like object into training function.

items.title: Switch to 1.0.x version
items.body: As long as all issues fixed in upstream.

items.title: HashBackup version of zstd Python module
What is default level for zstd.compress(data)?
items.body:
If `zstd.compress(data)` is called without an argument for `level`, what level does it default to? According to python docs for `zlib.compress(string, level)` the default `level` is `6`, and `level` is a range from `0-9`: https://docs.python.org/2/library/zlib.html

You mentioned the range for `level` in `zstd.compress(data, level)` is from `1-20` (https://github.com/sergey-dryabzhinsky/python-zstd/issues/6#issuecomment-228926620). What is its default? I tried checking https://github.com/Cyan4973/zstd but did not find a default.

Thanks.

items.title: How do I use this?
items.body:
Hi Sergey,

Thanks for putting this together. I think I've figured out how to install it, but am unsure how to invoke it from a script. 

I try `import zstd` but I get a `ImportError: No module named zstd`

For install, this is what I did (I do not have permission to install to the system directories):

```
git clone https://github.com/sergey-dryabzhinsky/python-zstd 
cd python-zstd
git submodule update --init
python setup.py build clean
PYTHONPATH=<path_to_a_custom_directory> python setup.py install --install-lib=<path_to_a_custom_directory>
```

This results in `ls <path_to_a_custom_directory>` returning `easy-install.pth  site.py  site.pyc  zstd-0.6.1-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg`

Then in my code I have:

```
sys.path.append(<path_to_a_custom_directory>)
import zstd
```
1. How do I import zstd into my script?
2. How do I call zstd from my script? Can I do it like zlib? Example:

```
compressed_msg = zlib.compress(msg.encode('utf-8'), level)
```

Where `level` is an integer from `0` through `9` referring to the `zlib compression level`.

items.title: Update to 0.4 upstream version
items.body:
- new compression magic
- remove useless level-1 switch to previous version
- decompression of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 - is automatic now (inside zstd)

items.title: Decompress by v0.3 not compatible with data compressed by v0.0.1 and v0.0.2 versions
items.body:
Need to:
- add super-old version, without magic numbers
- try to decompress by new function,
- if not, try v0.0.2 function,
- if not - error

items.title: Setuptools module deprecated
items.body: Should use distutils module.

items.title: Update ZSTD to 0.3 version
items.body: And add support of new high compression levels.
